com.codename1.rad.controllers

Class Controller

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.codename1.rad.controllers.Controller
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ActionListener<ControllerEvent>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ApplicationController, AppSectionController, NavigationController, ViewController

    public class Controller
extends Object
implements ActionListener<ControllerEvent>

    A base class for all Controller classes.

    Each application should implement a single ApplicationController class which will be used as the app’s main lifecycle class. Forms should all have associated FormController classes. In some cases, for more complex views, you may also want to have a dedicated ViewController for the view also.

    Controller Hierarchy

    Similar to Component, controllers have a hierarchy that is used for managing user navigation and event dispatch. A Controller may have a "parent" controller. All events received by a Controller will propagate up to its parent controller if it isn’t consumed. Additionally, FormController views its "parent" controller as the previous form for navigation purposes. E.g. If a FormController has a parent controller that is also a FormController, then it will automatically add a "back" event to its form so that the user will return to the "parent" controller’s form when the user selects "back".

    Actions and Events

    The primary mechanism for receiving notification about user actions is via Actions. The controller defines the action, and the passes it to the view, associating it with ActionNode.Category. If the EntityView supports that ActionNode.Category it will fire an ActionNode.ActionNodeEvent event which the controller can process.

    For example, the ProfileAvatarView view supports the ProfileAvatarView.PROFILE_AVATAR_CLICKED category so a controller can register an action with that view as follows:

    public class MyViewController extends ViewController {
    public static final ActionNode showDetails = UI.action(icon(FontImage.MATERIAL_INFO)); (1)
    public MyViewController(Controller parent, Entity profile) {
        super(parent);
        setLayout(new BorderLayout());
        ProfileAvatarView view = new ProfileAvatarView(profile, new ViewNode(
            actions(ProfileAvatarView.PROFILE_AVATAR_CLICKED, showDetails) (2)
        ), 10);
        addActionListener(showDetails, evt->{ (3)
            evt.consume();

            new ProfileDetailsController(this, profile).getView().show(); (4)
        });
    }

}

    1. We define the action. It doesn’t need be static or public. It just needs to be addressable within the Controller. I make it public and static so that it is also easily accessible by other controllers that may want to listen for that action.

    2. We add the showDetails action to the ViewNode of the `ProfileAvatarView’s `PROFILE_AVATAR_CLICKED category so that it knows to fire that action when users click on the avatar.

    3. We add a listener for the showDetails action so that we can handle the event where a user clicks on the avatar.

    4. This is a made up class ProfileDetailsController, but we assume it is a subclass of FormController, and it shows the details for a profile.

    Author:
    shannah

    • Method Detail

      • addEventListener

        public void addEventListener(ActionListener<ControllerEvent> l)

        Adds a controller listener. Controller listeners are notified of Controller events that are dispatched using dispatchEvent(ControllerEvent).

        This is the means by which information propagates up the controller hierarchy from views and sub-controllers.

        Parameters:
        l -

      • removeEventListener

        public void removeEventListener(ActionListener<ControllerEvent> l)

        Parameters:

        l - The listener.

      • removeActionListener

        public void removeActionListener(ActionNode action,
                                 ActionListener<ActionNode.ActionNodeEvent> l)

      • dispatchEvent

        protected void dispatchEvent(ControllerEvent evt)

        Dispatches an event first to listeners of this controller, and then, if not consumed yet, to listeners of the parent controller. The event will propagate up the controller hierarchy until it is either consumed, or until it reaches the top of the hierarchy (i.e. parent == null).

        Parameters:
        evt - The event to be dispatched.

      • getParent

        public Controller getParent()

        Gets the parent controller for this controller. All controllers except for the ApplicationController should have a parent. This controller hierarchy is used to keep a navigation history also. For example, the parent controller of a FormController is the "previous" form. Hence the back command of a FormController will go "back" to the parent controller’s form.

        Returns:

      • actionPerformed

        public void actionPerformed(ControllerEvent evt)

        Should be overridden by subclasses to handle ControllerEvent s. This is the cornerstone of how information is passed "up" the controller hierarchy, from the view. The view or sub-controller, dispatches an event. The event propagates up the controller hierarchy, until a controller consumes the event.

        Specified by:
        actionPerformed in interface ActionListener<ControllerEvent>
        Parameters:
        evt -

      • getFormController

        public FormController getFormController()

        Gets the FormController for the current controller context. This will walk up the controller hierarchy (i.e. getParent() until it finds an instance of FormController. If none is found, it returns null.

        Returns:
        The FormController, or null if none found.

      • getFormController

        public FormController getFormController(int maxDistance)

        Returns the FormController in this hierarchy if it can be found within a maximum distance when traversing up the controller hierarchy. When maxDistance=0, this will only return non-null if this is a FormController instance. When maxDistance=1, this will only return non-null if either this or the parent controller is a FormController. Etc…​

        Parameters:
        maxDistance - The maximum distance to walk up the controller hierarchy to find a FormController before returning null.
        Returns:
        The FormController or null if none found within the specified distance.

        Gets the section controller for the current controller context. This will walk up the controller hierarchy until it finds an instance of AppSectionController.

        Returns:
        The AppSectionController, or null if none found.

        Returns:

      • setParent

        public void setParent(Controller parent)

        Sets the parent controller for this controller.

        Parameters:
        parent -

      • createViewNode

        protected ViewNode createViewNode()

        Creates the view node that should be used as the node for the controller’s view. This method should be overridden by subclasses to define the default view node, but this method shouldn’t be called directly. Rather the getViewNode() method should be called so that the view node is only created once. getViewNode() will also set the parent node to the view node of the parent controller to more easily benefit from inherited attributes in the UI descriptor hierarchy.

        Returns:
        A ViewNode

      • getViewNode

        public ViewNode getViewNode()

        Gets the ViewNode that should be used as the view model for views of this controller. Subclasses should override createViewNode() to define the view node for the controller. This method will defer to that for the initial view node creation, and then just return that view node on subsequeuent calls.

        Note
        		 This will automatically set the parent node of the view node to the view node of the parent controller.
        Returns:

      • lookup

        public <T> T lookup(Class<T> type)

        Obtains an object of the given type that has been previously registered by this controller (or a parent controller) via the addLookup(java.lang.Object) method. This facilitates the creation of shared objects that can be accessed by controllers and all of their descendants. For example, the ApplicationController might register a webservice client via addLookup() so that all controllers in the application can obtain a reference to this client via a simple lookup.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type object to look up.
        Parameters:
        type - The type of object to look up.
        Returns:
        The object, or null if none was registered.

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        Since:

      • withLookupEntity

        public boolean withLookupEntity(Class type,
                                SuccessCallback<Entity> callback)

        Looks up an entity of a given class, and executes the provided callback with it if the entity is found.

        Parameters:

        callback - Call back that is only called if the lookup finds a match.
        Returns:

        Since:

      • fillSlot

        public void fillSlot(Tag slotId,
                     ActionListener<FillSlotEvent> l)

        Adds a listener to be notified when the Slot placeholder with the given ID is requesting to be filled.

        Parameters:
        slotId - The ID of the slot that you wish to fill with this handler.
        l - Listener that is called when a slot with the given ID is requesting to be filled. To set content in the slot you can obtain a reference to the slot via FillSlotEvent.getSlot() and call Slot.setContent(Component) on it. Make sure you call ActionEvent.consume() if you set the content to prevent the event from bubbling up the controller hierarchy and being overridden by another controller.
        Since:
        2.0

      • onStopController

        protected void onStopController()

        A lifecycle method that should be used to cleanup variables and listeners that were setup in the onStartController() method. Lookups, actions, and the view node are automatically cleared when the controller is stopped, so you don’t have to worry about cleaning up things like that.

        However, you should clean up any variables that you initialized in onStartController().

        When live-content reloading is enabled in the Codename One simulator, it will trigger refresh() which stops and starts the controller hierarchy.

        Since:
        2.0
        See Also:
        onStartController(), refresh()

      • onStartController

        protected void onStartController()

        A lifecycle method that shoudl be used to setup the controller. Use this instead of the constructor as this will allow you to work nicely with live content reloading. When live-content reloading is enabled in the Codename One simulator, it will trigger refresh() which stops and starts the controller hierarchy.

        When this method is run, you can assume that the parent controller is already in the "started" state.

      • startController

        public final void startController()

        Starts the given controller. This will trigger the onStartController() method, which should be used for setup instead of the constructor.

        Since:
        2.0
        See Also:
        onStartController(), onStopController()

      • start

        public static <T extends Controller> T start(T controller)

        Static method that starts a given controller, and returns the controller back for chaining.

        Type Parameters:
        T -
        Parameters:
        controller - The controller to start.
        Returns:
        The controller.
        Since:
        2.0

      • isStarted

        public boolean isStarted()

        Checks if the controller is started. Controllers follow multiple lifecycles. This "started" flag pertains to the "start/stop" lifecycle. When the app is "reloaded" due to resource changes, then the onStopController() method is triggered, which cleans up all of the controller’s resources. Then the startController()} method is triggered, which creates them again. This is used to allow live reloading of changes.

        Returns:
        True if the controller is in "started" state.
        See Also:
        startController(), onStartController(), onStopController()

      • refresh

        public void refresh()

        Refreshes the controller. This calls onStopController() and startController() and is useful for reloading the application when changes are made to the classes or resources.

      • extendAction

        public ActionNode extendAction(ActionNode.Category category,
                               boolean overwriteAttributes,
                               Attribute... attributes)

        Extends an existing action from one of the parent controllers, and registers it as an action on this controller.

        Parameters:
        category - The category to register the action to.
        overwriteAttributes - Whether to overwrite existing attributes of the action. If false, attributes provided will be ignored when extending actions that already have those attributes defined.
        attributes - Attributes to add to the action.
        Returns:
        The action that was added.
        Since:
        2.0

      • extendAction

        public ActionNode extendAction(ActionNode.Category category,
                               SuccessCallback<ActionNode> callback)

        Extends an action from a parent controller, and registers it as an action on this controller.

        Parameters:
        category - The category to register the action to.
        callback - Callback which is executed immediately on the action, which is used to configure the action.
        Returns:
        The action node that was added/extended.
        See Also:
        extendAction(ActionNode.Category, boolean, Attribute[])

      • getInheritedAction

        public ActionNode getInheritedAction(ActionNode.Category category)

        Gets the first action matching the given category that is registered on this controller or one of the controller’s parents. If none is found, it will return null.

        Parameters:
        category - The category of action to return.
        Returns:
        A matching action or null if none is found.
        Since:
        2.0 hierarchy.
        See Also:
        to retrieve an action from this controller only., To retrieve multiple actions from the controller

      • getInheritedActions

        public Actions getInheritedActions(ActionNode.Category category,
                                   boolean aggregate)

        Gets actions registered in the specified category on this controller or parents.

        Parameters:
        category - The category of action to retrieve.
        aggregate - If true, then this will return a set of all actions in this category, registered in this controller, and all of its parents - combined together. If false, then this will return the set of actions in this category in the first controller that contains at least one action in this category, starting with this container, and walking up the controller hierarchy until it finds one with at least one action in this category.
        Returns:
        A set of matching actions.
        Since:
        2.0
        See Also:
        To retrieve only actions registered on this controller., To retrieve only a single action.

      • getAction

        public ActionNode getAction(ActionNode.Category category)

        Gets an action in the specified category that is registered on this controller.

        Parameters:
        category - The category of action to look for.
        Returns:
        A matching ActionNode or null if this controller has no action registered in that category.
        Since:
        2.0
        See Also:
        #getActions(ActionNode.Category)} to get multiple actions in the category., #getInheritedAction(ActionNode.Category)} To check parent controllers for actions as well.

      • getActions

        public Actions getActions(ActionNode.Category category)

        Gets actions registered in this Controller in the specified category. This does not check the parent for actions. If there are no actions registered on this controller then it will return an empty Actions.

        Parameters:
        category - The category of action to retrieve.
        Returns:
        An Actions object with all of the actions that are registered in this controller for that category.
        Since:
        2.0
        See Also:
        #getInheritedActions(ActionNode.Category, boolean)} To retrieve all actions in this controller and its parent(s)., #getAction(ActionNode.Category)} to retrieve only a single action in the category.

      • getActionsNode

        public ActionsNode getActionsNode(ActionNode.Category category,
                                  boolean aggregate)

        Gets an actions node for the given category such that it can be added directly to a ViewNode. This method is usually called inside createViewNode() for adding actions to the view node.

        Parameters:
        category -
        aggregate -
        Returns:
        Since:
        2.0

      • getSingleActionsNode

        public ActionsNode getSingleActionsNode(ActionNode.Category category)

        Gets a single ActionNode for the given category. This is a convenience method that you can use in implementations of createViewNode() to easily get an ActionsNode that is ready to add to the view node.

        This uses getInheritedAction(ActionNode.Category) to find the action.

        Parameters:
        category - The category of action we wish to retrieve.
        Returns:
        An ActionsNode with zero or one action registered with the given category.
        Since:
        2.0
        See Also:
        getInheritedAction(ActionNode.Category)

      • initControllerActions

        protected void initControllerActions()

        This can be used to initialize actions that the controller uses. It is called just before startController(), and it can be overridden by subclasses to provide further modifications to actions that have been initialized.

        Generally this would include calls to #addActions(ActionNode.Category, ActionNode…​) and extendAction(ActionNode.Category, SuccessCallback).

        Since:
        2.0

      • createObjectWithFactory

        public <T> T createObjectWithFactory(Class<T> type,
                                     Object[] params)

        This will attempt to create an object of the given type using registered factories. It will pass the event up the controller hierarchy.

        Type Parameters:
        T -
        Parameters:
        type - The type of object to create
        Returns:
        A newly created object of the given type, or null if no factories were registered.
